title: Grinder & Machine Compatibility Matrix
description: Find out which Arco grinder pairs best with which Arco machine. Every combination is rated for compatibility, with budget tiers and pairing rationale to help you build the right setup.
hero_image_alt: Four Arco grinders lined up beside three espresso machines on a marble countertop, showing scale and pairing combinations

machines.label: Arco Automatico
machines.notes: Has built-in grinder; external grinder optional for single-dose workflow

pairings.rationale: Perfect budget pairing. The Mini Grinder produces adequate grind for the Steam's pressurized basket.
Good starter combination. The Mini Grinder handles the Nano's 53mm portafilter well. Upgrade the grinder first when you outgrow this setup.
Not recommended. The Automatico's built-in grinder outperforms the Mini for convenience and consistency.
The Classica deserves a better grinder. The Mini Grinder's 38mm burrs cannot provide the consistency the Classica's PID system can exploit.
Severe bottleneck. The Barista Pro's capabilities will be wasted with inconsistent grinds from small burrs.
Not recommended. Lever machines demand precise, consistent grind quality.
Severe mismatch. Invest in the Macinino Pro or Conico instead.
Do not pair entry-level grinders with high-end machines.
Overkill for the Steam, but fine if you plan to upgrade the machine later.
Excellent pairing. The Macinino Home elevates the Nano significantly, unlocking its full potential.
A nice upgrade for single-dosing, but the Automatico's built-in grinder is already quite capable.
The recommended pairing. The 50mm flat burrs deliver the consistency the Classica's PID needs, and the combined price point is excellent.
Solid pairing. The Macinino Home is capable enough for the Barista Pro, though upgrading to the Pro grinder unlocks more potential.
Adequate but not ideal. Lever machines benefit from the larger burrs and lower RPM of the Conico.
The Maestro deserves the Macinino Pro for grind quality parity.
Underpowered for this machine. The Dual Boiler's temperature precision demands equally precise grind.
Extreme overkill. Save your money and get the Nano instead.
The grinder outclasses the machine, but it means you can upgrade the machine later without changing grinder.
Specialty pairing for those who want conical burr flavour profiles with automatic convenience.
Great match if you prefer the rounder, sweeter flavour profile of conical burrs.
A strong combination. Conical burrs pair well with the Barista Pro's gentle pre-infusion.
The ideal lever pairing. Conical burrs produce a forgiving particle distribution that works beautifully with manual pressure profiling.
Very capable. Choose this over the Macinino Pro if you prefer traditional Italian espresso flavour.
Capable but the Dual Boiler's precision-focused design pairs better with the surgical accuracy of flat burrs.
Absurd mismatch. You would be grinding diamonds to make mud pies.
Significant overkill. The Nano cannot exploit the Pro's precision. Only justified if upgrading the machine soon.
For the single-dose purist who wants peak grind quality with automatic brewing. Niche but valid.
Future-proof pairing. You will notice the difference in clarity over the Macinino Home.
Outstanding match. The 64mm flat burrs deliver the clarity and detail the Barista Pro was designed to showcase.
Excellent if you want bright, complex espresso. Flat burrs highlight origin character more than conicals.
The flagship pairing. This is Arco's recommended setup for discerning home baristas who want cafe-quality results.
The ultimate home setup. Both components operate at the highest level, and neither bottlenecks the other.
